title: Case 7-7: Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
chief_complaint: I have noticed considerable problems hearing in general, especially when there is background noise, for about a year. I also feel like I've been stuttering for the past two years and sometimes I hear voices.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing difficulties noticed approximately 1 year prior; stuttering began 2 years prior.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Minor auditory hallucinations (hearing voices), stuttering, mild memory issues (though not evident in interview).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Considerable difficulty in background noise; however, performs well on everyday living tasks.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Determine if hearing problems are central (linked to dementia) or peripheral.

history.present_illness: Patient is a physician in his mid-60s recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's. He traveled a long distance for evaluation. Reports hearing loss in noise and stuttering. Wife corroborates he does well on daily tasks.
history.noise_exposure_history: No positive history for noise exposure.
history.patient_goals: Differentiation of central vs. peripheral pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild, bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition in quiet was essentially normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Central Auditory Processing Tests
tests.key_findings: Behavioral central tests showed major deficits. Severe left ear deficits were noted on all dichotic speech tests. A mild right ear deficit was noted on the SSW (though graph suggests lower scores). Bilateral deficits noted on compressed speech and frequency patterns.

tests.name: Electrophysiology (MLR)
tests.key_findings: Test completed but fraught with artifact; difficult to interpret results. P300 was not completed due to time constraints.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient exhibits a mild peripheral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss that does not fully explain his significant difficulties in noise. Central testing reveals severe left-ear deficits on dichotic tasks (consistent with right hemisphere or interhemispheric involvement often seen in Alzheimer's) and bilateral deficits in temporal processing (compressed speech/frequency patterns). The pattern suggests significant central auditory involvement superimposed on mild peripheral loss.
counseling_points: Discussed the likelihood of central auditory involvement contributing to hearing difficulties beyond the mild peripheral loss.
Explained that the 'left ear deficit' on central tests does not mean the ear itself is worse, but relates to how the brain processes sound.
Discussed amplification options: Hearing aids vs. Assistive Listening Devices (ALDs).

Recommended exploring ALDs over traditional hearing aids, as patients with dementia may struggle with the manipulation and maintenance of hearing aids, while ALDs can provide better signal-to-noise improvement for specific communication needs.
Discussed fundamental communication strategies with the patient and his wife.
notes_for_actor: Portray a physician in his mid-60s who is articulate but has recently started stuttering.
You are mildly forgetful but generally function well; the dementia is in early stages.
You are frustrated because you can hear sounds but cannot understand them in noise.
You mention 'hearing voices' occasionally but describe them as minor hallucinations.
You are intellectually curious about whether your problem is 'brain' or 'ear'.
